docs.lead_paragraph: Our clinic computers went on the blink last week, and work ground to a halt. The receptionists couldn't confirm scheduled appointments or make new ones. The nurses had no way to record vital signs or transmit phone messages. The billers couldn't bill. We doctors couldn't read our old notes or write new ones. We couldn't figure out if Mr. Jones needed blood tests today (as we suspected) or if he could put them off until November (as he maintained). We couldn't click the mouse once to prescribe a dozen medications; now every slip had to be laboriously written out by hand. And who remembers how to spell pyrazinamide anyway, let alone what size pills it comes in?

headline.main: When the Computers Crash, All That's Left Are the Patients

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger commentary suggests that computerization of hospitals and medical facilities has taken emphasis off direct communication with patients; holds that although Secretary of Health and Human Services Tommy Thompson is in favor of more computer involvement in health care, human error cannot yet be eliminated from technological advances; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Perhaps more computers or wiser computers are the solution to human errors, but sometimes it is tempting to wish for fewer, dumber computers instead.

docs.lead_paragraph: One day a few years ago, Doris Stowens saw the monsters from Maurice Sendak's ''Where the Wild Things Are'' stomping into her bedroom. Then the creatures morphed into traditional Thai dancers with long brass fingernails, whose furious dance took them from the floor to the walls to the ceiling. Although shocked to witness such a spectacle, Ms. Stowens, 85, was aware that she was having hallucinations, and she was certain that they had something to do with the fact that she suffered from the eye disease macular degeneration.

headline.main: When the Vision Goes, the Hallucinations Begin

docs.snippet: Charles Bonnet syndrome causes people with vision problems to hallucinate.
